name: Japanese Mythology
participants: Susanoo - Storm god whose violence triggers crisis
Ame-no-Uzume - Goddess whose dance lures Amaterasu out
Omoikane - Wisdom god who devises the plan
Tajikara-wo - Strong deity who pulls boulder away

narrativeStructure.provocation: Susanoo's escalating crimes - destroyed rice paddies, polluted harvest hall, killed weaving maiden
narrativeStructure.ritualSolution: Sacred ceremony to lure Amaterasu out through curiosity and celebration
narrativeStructure.divineCouncil: Eight million kami gather at Heavenly River led by Omoikane (Wisdom God)
narrativeStructure.consequence: Eternal darkness covers both heaven and earth, evil spirits multiply
narrativeStructure.resolution: Amaterasu emerges, light returns, Susanoo is punished and exiled
narrativeStructure.withdrawal: Amaterasu, horrified and grieving, seals herself in cave with boulder

description: The myth of Amaterasu hiding in the Heavenly Rock Cave is one of the most celebrated stories in Japanese mythology, recorded in the Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE). When Amaterasu, the sun goddess, sealed herself in a cave to escape her brother Susanoo's violent rampage, the world plunged into eternal darkness. The myth explains the origins of sacred Shinto rituals, especially kagura dance, and illustrates how cleverness, cooperation, and sacred celebration can overcome even cosmic calamity.

ritualElements.amenoUzume: Goddess performs ecstatic dance that makes gods laugh
ritualElements.sakakiTree: Sacred tree hung with mirrors, jewels, and offerings
ritualElements.sacredRooster: Nagaki-no-tori roosters crow to announce dawn in darkness
ritualElements.curiosity: Amaterasu emerges to see what causes divine laughter
ritualElements.sacredMirror: Yata-no-Kagami crafted to reflect Amaterasu's light

significance.shintoValues: Community action, ritual purity, divine accessibility through proper ceremony
significance.ritualOrigins: Explains origin of kagura (sacred Shinto dance)
significance.conflictResolution: Cooperation, cleverness, and celebration overcome violence and chaos
significance.imperialRegalia: Three Sacred Treasures of Japan originate in this myth (mirror, jewel, sword)
significance.solarMythology: Eclipse myth - sun's disappearance and return

historicalContext.setting: Takamagahara (High Plain of Heaven) and Ama-no-Iwato (Heavenly Rock Cave)
historicalContext.sources: Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE)
historicalContext.climacticViolation: Susanoo hurled flayed horse through roof during sacred weaving, killing a maiden
historicalContext.triggeringEvent: Susanoo's violent rampage destroying rice fields, polluting sacred spaces
